msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to unknown, Philadelphia March 4, 1824

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworthâ€™s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, including non-standard spelling, line breaks, and hyphenation of words. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
You have obliged me much by the
present you have made me, Sir, of your
travels in Europe - Though they could
not contain so much positive novelty
for us as they do for the Americans
yet they will not be less interesting
to the old than to the new World

. The interest of curiosity may not be
so great but that of self love is still
greater. We are anxious to see how
European things and persons strike
Americans - It happens that you
have given accounts of persons and
things in England, Scotland, France
Geneva, and
Swisserland Switzerland
, which my sisters
& I have recently visited - And many of the
persons whom you mention are our
particular friends. To the justice and
spirit of all the delineations of what
we have seen we can bear full testimony
and from these we are reasonably led to
infer
that all your representations of what
we have not seen are equally accurate.

Your account of the Manufactures
of the Hield for one instance, gives as
much information as possible in a small
compass & must therefore be valuable
to foreigners who are most curious to know
how the toys in the great Toy shop of
Europe are produced with such celerity
and perfection - I am sorry you did not see
Birmingham - and Watts |-
Your work has reached me but
a few days and I have not yet finish
ed finished reading it; but as I have an oppor-
-tunity opportunity of writing sending this letter
by a person who is going to
Philadel-
-phiaPhiladelphia
Philadelphia I cannot delay to offer you my
acknowledgements though they must
be insufficient as I have not yet
seen the extent of my obligation
I have seen enough however to
judge of the spirit of candor and li-
berality liberality and the freedom from na-
tional national jealousy evinced in your work
- I wish that this spirit which does
so much honor to the character of the
each individual & which is the true policy
of every nation, were more general
between America and England-
It is now becoming fashionable
indeed in London to speak well of
Americans & I hope the fashion of
writing with liberality will follow in
among our best authors & yours.
Washington Irvine Irving
has set an ex-
cellent excellent example - In others of your
writers & of panegyrists of their
country I have regretted to observe
the talents they individually possess
and the grand facts they had to pro-
duce produce in favor of America marred
and disgraced by this sort of national
spirit of monopoly &depreciation
Let them raise & glorify their country
& exult in her talents & triumphs in
arts & sciences as much as they will
in this they may be sure of the concurrence
of the wise and the sympathy of the
good, and the indulgence of all. Even
if they exaggerate a little in favor
of their country it is an amicable weak-
ness weakness for which there should be, & is, a
give=and=take=charter give-and-take charter granted by the common custom,
more powerful than the common-
law common law of nations - But the moment
any one nation or one world begins
to depreciate the other, indulgence
& sympathy cease - & the just informer
is that those who attempt to knock
down others that they may raise them-
-selves themselves upon the fallen bodies are consci-
ous conscious that they can not are inferior

May this insidious and degrading
spirit cease on both sides the Atlantic! Let us all
try to raise ourselves without lower
-ing lowering others! - May public esteem be
the just reward of every writer, who acts
this laudable example & who pre-
serves preserves , temper & candor even when
goaded by illiberal criticism or
tempted by vulgar example!

I am Sir your obliged Servt
Maria Edgeworth
